articles.headline: Fictional Disaster, Made to Sound Real, Draws F.C.C. Fine
articles.snippet: An effort to grab viewers’ attention and send them to the movie theater may have worked a little too well for Comcast, Viacom and Disney.
articles.abstract: An effort to grab viewers’ attention and send them to the movie theater may have worked a little too well for Comcast, Viacom and Disney.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The familiar, piercing tone of an emergency alert jolted television viewers to attention. Then came the frightening images: the White House surrounded by terrorists, landmarks in flames in the nation’s capital and military convoys patrolling the city. “THIS IS NOT A TEST,” read the on-screen advisory.

articles.headline: Battling a Bank to Collect a Judgment
articles.snippet: Maury Rosenberg says he lost his business after being forced into involuntary bankruptcy by a unit of U.S. Bancorp. A court later ruled the bankruptcy illegal, but by then the business was gone.
articles.abstract: Maury Rosenberg says he lost his business after being forced into involuntary bankruptcy by a unit of U.S. Bancorp. A court later ruled the bankruptcy illegal, but by then the business was gone.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not exactly David v. Goliath, but it’s close.

articles.headline: From Russia, ‘Tourists’ Stir the Protests
articles.snippet: “Protest tourists” from across the border are joining demonstrations by ethnic Russians in southern and eastern Ukraine.
articles.abstract: “Protest tourists” from across the border are joining demonstrations by ethnic Russians in southern and eastern Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Around the south and east of Ukraine, in vital cities in the country’s industrial heartland, ethnic Russians have staged demonstrations and stormed buildings demanding a wider invasion of their country by Moscow.

articles.headline: Wishing They All Could Be California Hens
articles.snippet: California voters in 2008 approved a measure requiring more generous living conditions for hens, but the state’s decision to require imported eggs to be produced under the same standards has drawn a lawsuit.
articles.abstract: California voters in 2008 approved a measure requiring more generous living conditions for hens, but the state’s decision to require imported eggs to be produced under the same standards has drawn a lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATWATER, Calif. — Hens in California are living the good life. Many can now lay their eggs in oversize enclosures roomy enough to stand up, lie down — even extend their wings fully without touching another bird.

articles.headline: Top Russians Face Sanctions by U.S. for Crimea Crisis
articles.snippet: The Obama administration suspended military ties to Russia, including exercises, port visits and planning meetings, just a day after calling off trade talks.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration suspended military ties to Russia, including exercises, port visits and planning meetings, just a day after calling off trade talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States prepared Monday to impose sanctions on high-level Russian officials involved in the military occupation of Crimea, as the escalating crisis in Ukraine prompted turmoil in global markets, pounding the Russian ruble and driving up energy prices.

articles.headline: As Prime Russian Trading Partner, Germany Appears Crucial to Ending Crisis
articles.snippet: With Russia’s economy in a downturn, Germany could be in a prime spot to leverage a peaceful end to the upheaval in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: With Russia’s economy in a downturn, Germany could be in a prime spot to leverage a peaceful end to the upheaval in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the face of the diplomatic maneuvering over how to confront a bellicose Russia in Ukraine, one country appears to hold the key to any long-lasting entente: Germany, Europe’s economic powerhouse and one of Russia’s primary trading partners.

articles.headline: Cities Mobilize to Help Those Threatened by Gentrification
articles.snippet: While still eager to have young professionals move to blighted areas, cities are recognizing the toll that rising tax assessments can have on longtime working-class residents.
articles.abstract: While still eager to have young professionals move to blighted areas, cities are recognizing the toll that rising tax assessments can have on longtime working-class residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Cities that have worked for years to attract young professionals who might have once moved to the suburbs are now experimenting with ways to protect a group long deemed expendable — working- and lower-middle class homeowners threatened by gentrification.

articles.headline: Court Says BP’s Spill Agreement Is Binding
articles.snippet: A federal appeals panel ruled that BP must pay gulf companies for damages without requiring proof of harm by the Deepwater Horizon spill.
articles.abstract: A federal appeals panel ruled that BP must pay gulf companies for damages without requiring proof of harm by the Deepwater Horizon spill.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — In a setback for BP as it deals with the aftermath of the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill, a federal appeals court on Monday ruled that the company would have to stick to its agreement and pay some gulf businesses for economic damage without their having to prove it was caused by the spill.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and John Schwartz
